Federated Learning with Projected Trajectory Regularization

Abstract

Federated learning enables joint training of machine learning models from distributed clients without sharing their local data. One key challenge in federated learning is to handle non-identically distributed data across the clients, which leads to deteriorated model training performances. Prior works in this line of research mainly focus on utilizing last-step global model parameters/gradients or the linear combinations of the past model parameters/gradients, which do not fully exploit the potential of global information from the model training trajectory. In this paper, we propose a novel federated learning framework with projected trajectory regularization (FedPTR) for tackling the data heterogeneity issue, which proposes a unique way to better extract the essential global information from the model training trajectory. Specifically, FedPTR allows local clients or the server to optimize an auxiliary (synthetic) dataset that mimics the learning dynamics of the recent model update and utilizes it to project the next-step model trajectory for local training regularization. We conduct rigorous theoretical analysis for our proposed framework under nonconvex stochastic settings to verify its fast convergence under heterogeneous data distributions. Experiments on various benchmark datasets and non-i.i.d. settings validate the effectiveness of our proposed framework.

**footnotetext: Equal contribution.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) McMahan et al. (2017); Konečnỳ et al. (2016) has recently emerged as an attractive learning paradigm where a large number of remote clients (e.g., mobile devices, institutions, organizations) cooperate to jointly learn a machine learning model without data sharing. Specifically, Federated Learning works by performing local training on each client based on their own data, while having the clients communicate their local model updates to a global server McMahan et al. (2017); Konečnỳ et al. (2016). Specifically, FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017) updates the global model by averaging multiple steps of local stochastic gradient descent (SGD) updates. Though FedAvg has demonstrated empirical success on independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) client data, when facing the more practical non-i.i.d data distributions across the clients, it can lead to diverging updates and severe drift between the local and the global training objective in each client, which largely deteriorates the model training performance Khaled et al. (2020); Karimireddy et al. (2020b); Wang et al. (2020b).

To tackle this data heterogeneity issue, a line of research mainly focuses on utilizing or regularizing with the last-step global model parameters/gradients or the linear combinations of past model parameters/gradients Li et al. (2020); Karimireddy et al. (2020b); Gao et al. (2022). Specifically, FedProx Li et al. (2020) makes a simple modification to FedAvg by adding a proximal regularization term in the local training objective to restrict the local updates to be closer to the last-step global model. SCAFFOLD Karimireddy et al. (2020b) reduces client drift with a control variate that linearly accumulates past gradients and corrects for the drift. FedDC Gao et al. (2022) follows a similar idea as SCAFFOLD with a local drift term and introduces a linear gradient correction loss, attempting to further eliminate the drift at local training. However, such methods may not be sufficient enough to fully exploit global information to tackle extreme data heterogeneity. In order to better extract the essential global information from the model training trajectory, we propose a novel federated learning framework with projected trajectory regularization (FedPTR), to help guide the local model update. Specifically, during the local training, FedPTR allows local clients or the server to optimize an auxiliary dataset that mimics the learning dynamics of the recent model update and then utilizes it to project the next-step model trajectory for local training regularization. To achieve the above goal and optimize the auxiliary dataset, we adopt the Matching Training Trajectories (MTT) technique Cazenavette et al. (2022), which was originally proposed for the task of dataset distillation. Here we want to emphasize that our usage of the Matching Training Trajectories is actually different from traditional dataset distillation whose goal is to synthesize a small dataset such that models trained on the synthetic dataset can achieve similar test accuracy as if trained on the actual dataset. Firstly, most works in dataset distillation cannot fit in here as they usually require access to the entire training dataset which is not practical for federated learning. Some existing works Zhou et al. (2020); Song et al. (2022) aim to get around this by letting local clients distill their own data and send it to the server. However, this could incur extra communication costs and raise data privacy concerns. Secondly, the goal of dataset distillation is quite ambitious and usually requires obtaining multiple model training trajectories (or re-starts) in order to obtain barely satisfactory performance. In sharp contrast, here we only require the extracted auxiliary dataset to mimic the learning dynamics of recent model updates for projecting the next-step update, which is a much easier task that can be achieved with only one global model train trajectory.

We summarize our contribution as follows:

  • •

    We propose a novel federated learning framework FedPTR that handles extreme data heterogeneity across local clients. The proposed method allows each client or the server to extract essential global information from the observed global model training trajectory and utilize it to project the next-step model trajectory for local training regularization.

  • •

    We provide rigorous theoretical analysis and prove that FedPTR can achieve a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T) w.r.t total communication rounds T𝑇T under stochastic non-convex optimization settings, which matches the best existing results.

  • •

    We conduct extensive experiments on various benchmark datasets and non-i.i.d settings to demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed FedPTR in training real-world machine learning models.

2 Related Work

Federated Learning. Federated Learning McMahan et al. (2017) has been widely applied to all kinds of clients (e.g., mobile devices, institutions, and organizations) to collaboratively train a global model without sharing their private data. However, the heterogeneous data distribution across different devices comes to be one of the major bottlenecks for Federated Learning algorithms. Based on a similar idea as FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017), several federated optimization methods considered server-level momentum update such as FedAvgM Hsu et al. (2019), FedAGM Kim et al. (2022), FedCM Xu et al. (2021) or global-wise adaptive update such as FedAdagrad Reddi et al. (2020), FedYogi Reddi et al. (2020), FedAdam Reddi et al. (2020), FedAMS Wang et al. (2022b) which take advantage of both stable optimization methods and the federated learning paradigm. A similar strategy to improve the stability of federated learning optimization is adopting client-level optimization methods, including FedSAM and MoFedSAM Qu et al. (2022), MOON Li et al. (2021a) and FedPD Zhang et al. (2020). Moreover, personalized federated learning has also been discussed as the potential distribution across clients could be non-i.i.d. Several personalized federated learning approaches include meta-learning-based methods such as Per-FedAvg (Fallah et al., 2020), multi-task-learning-based method MOCHA (Smith et al., 2017) and hybrid global and local models such as APFL (Deng et al., 2020), Ditto (Li et al., 2021b), pFedMe (T Dinh et al., 2020), L2SGD (Hanzely and Richtárik, 2020), etc.

Federated Learning for Heterogeneous Data. Recent work showed that adding a proximal or regularization term during training helps mitigate the impact of statistical heterogeneity. FedProx Li et al. (2020) added a proximate term to help alleviate both system and statistical heterogeneity and improve model stability. FedDyn Acar et al. (2021) proposed a framework with local dynamic regularization terms to align with the global model. FedAGM Kim et al. (2022) introduced server gradient acceleration methods with regularization. Some others introduced extra control variables for alleviating data heterogeneity among devices. SCAFFOLD Karimireddy et al. (2020b) and Mime Karimireddy et al. (2020a) updated and communicated extra historical control variables during local updates to reduce the variance across clients. FedDC Gao et al. (2022) involved both dynamic regularization terms and local drift variables for model correction.

Dataset Distillation. Dataset distillation is proposed to learn a small synthetic dataset out of the original large dataset, such that the model trained on this small dataset can have a similar performance as the model trained on the original dataset. Wang et al. (2018) first introduced dataset distillation by gradient-based hyperparameter optimization. Bohdal et al. (2020) proposed a label distillation method to get soft labels for distilled images with the meta-learning framework.Zhao et al. (2021); Zhao and Bilen (2021a) proposed to match the gradient of the real dataset and the auxiliary dataset, and use data augmentation to boost the performance. Wang et al. (2022a); Zhao and Bilen (2021b) considered matching the distribution based on neural networks and largely reduced the memory cost. Recently, Matching Training Trajectories Cazenavette et al. (2022) and its variants Cazenavette et al. (2022); Liu et al. (2022); Du et al. (2022) are proposed to optimize the synthetic data by minimizing the distance between the synthetically trained parameters and the actual model training trajectories.

Federated Learning with Dataset Distillation. Several recent works have tried to combine federated learning with dataset distillation. Specifically, Zhou et al. (2020); Song et al. (2022) proposed a one-shot federated learning framework that allows all clients to distill their own dataset by local training and send the synthetic dataset to the server for centralized training. Xiong et al. (2022) proposes a multi-shot framework that clients will distill their dataset for every communication round. Note that the above-mentioned works require (distilled) data transmission between clients and server: clients need to send their local distilled data to the server. Yet this incurs extra communication costs and data privacy concerns. In sharp contrast, our algorithm maintains the same basic framework as traditional federated learning methods, where only the model parameters are synced between the server and clients.

3 Proposed Method

In this section, we introduce our proposed federated learning framework with Projected Trajectory Regularization (FedPTR) for tackling the data heterogeneity issue in federated learning.

Preliminaries on Federated Learning. Consider a federated system with N𝑁N total clients participated, the goal of federated learning is to optimize the following objective function:

min𝐰∈ℝd​∑i=1NmiM​ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i),subscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖𝑀ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖\min_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{m_{i}}{M}\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i}), (1)

where ℒℒ\mathcal{L} denotes the loss function such as Cross Entropy loss, 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} denotes the training data on client i𝑖i. Let mi=|𝒟i|subscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖m_{i}=|\mathcal{D}_{i}| be the cardinality of 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and we have M=∑i=1Nmi𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑚𝑖M=\sum_{i=1}^{N}m_{i} as total size of the training dataset. FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017) is designed to solve Eq (1) by coordinating multiple devices via a central server. Specifically, in each round of FedAvg, the server will broadcast the current global model 𝐰tsuperscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{t} to the clients. Each client will locally optimize the corresponding component function in Eq (1) and obtain the local model 𝐰it+1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{i}^{t+1}, i.e., 𝐰it+1=argmin𝐰ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1subscriptargmin𝐰ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}^{t+1}=\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\mathbf{w}}\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i}), through multiple steps of stochastic gradient descent. The server will then aggregate (weighted average) the local models {𝐰it+1}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1𝑖1𝑁\{\mathbf{w}_{i}^{t+1}\}_{i=1}^{N} to obtain the new global model.

FedProx Li et al. (2020) is another representative work which is designed to tackle both the data heterogeneity issue in federated learning and allows flexible performances on each of the local clients. Specifically, it allows the local objectives to be solved inexactly such that the amount of local computation/communication can be adapted for different clients with different amounts of resources. To formally define this inexactness, Li et al. (2020) introduced the following definition:

Definition 3.1 (γ𝛾\gamma-Inexactness).

Given a function h​(𝐰,𝐰0)=ℒ​(𝐰)+λ2​‖𝐰−𝐰0‖22ℎ𝐰subscript𝐰0ℒ𝐰𝜆2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐰subscript𝐰022h(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{w}_{0})=\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}_{0}\|_{2}^{2} and γ∈[0,1]𝛾01\gamma\in[0,1], 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} is a γ𝛾\gamma-inexact solution of min𝐰⁡h​(𝐰,𝐰0)subscript𝐰ℎ𝐰subscript𝐰0\min_{\mathbf{w}}h(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{w}_{0}) if ‖∇h​(𝐰∗,𝐰0)‖2≤γ​‖∇h​(𝐰0,𝐰0)‖2subscriptnorm∇ℎsuperscript𝐰subscript𝐰02𝛾subscriptnorm∇ℎsubscript𝐰0subscript𝐰02\|\nabla h(\mathbf{w}^{*},\mathbf{w}_{0})\|_{2}\leq\gamma\|\nabla h(\mathbf{w}_{0},\mathbf{w}_{0})\|_{2}.

Additionally, FedProx introduced a proximal term to the local objective to limit the local updates to be not too far away from its initial global model: 𝐰it+1=argmin𝐰ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)+λ2​∥𝐰−𝐰t∥22,superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1subscriptargmin𝐰ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖𝜆2subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐰superscript𝐰𝑡22\mathbf{w}_{i}^{t+1}=\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\mathbf{w}}\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i})+\frac{\lambda}{2}\lVert\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{t}\rVert^{2}_{2}, where λ𝜆\lambda controls the strength of the proximal term. We can observe that FedProx handles data heterogeneity by restricting the local updates to stay close to the initial global model.

3.1 Proposed Method

Due to the privacy-preserving design of federated learning, each client can only access their own training data. Therefore, the global model training trajectories contain all the information each client could possibly access with regard to other clients’ local training data. Naturally, most existing works seek help from global models or global variables to mitigate the data heterogeneity issue. Different from existing works which mainly focus on utilizing only the last-step global model or the linear combination of past global models, FedPTR aims to provide a better way to exploit the global information hidden in the model training trajectories via Matching Training Trajectories (MTT) Cazenavette et al. (2022). More specifically, we aim to extract an auxiliary dataset from the recent model training trajectories that could mimic the learning dynamics of the recent model update. Thus we can utilize such an auxiliary dataset for projecting the next-step training trajectory and provide better guidance to the local model training.

Extract Global Information via MTT. We found Matching Training Trajectories (MTT) Cazenavette et al. (2022) to be a perfect tool for our global information extraction purpose. The general goal of MTT is to learn an informative but small synthetic dataset that approximates the true learning trajectories.

Moreover, it only requires model parameters from previous training epochs which naturally fit the setting of federated learning. We summarize the detailed MTT process in Algorithm 1. Specifically, we treat the last model in the actual training trajectories (denoted by 𝐰endsuperscript𝐰end{\mathbf{w}}^{\text{end}}) as the teacher model in MTT and build a student model 𝐰^^𝐰\widehat{\mathbf{w}}, which is obtained by multiple steps of gradient descent training on the synthetic dataset 𝒟~~𝒟\widetilde{\mathcal{D}} starting from 𝐰startsuperscript𝐰start{\mathbf{w}}^{\text{start}} in the trajectory. By requiring the student model to stay close to the teacher model, we force MTT to learn a synthetic dataset 𝒟~~𝒟\widetilde{\mathcal{D}} that well-represents the recent learning dynamics. In detail, we have the following MTT loss:

ℒMTT​(𝒟~)=∥𝐰^−𝐰end∥22/∥𝐰end−𝐰start∥22,subscriptℒMTT~𝒟subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝐰superscript𝐰end22subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝐰endsuperscript𝐰start22\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{MTT}}(\widetilde{\mathcal{D}})=\lVert\widehat{\mathbf{w}}-{\mathbf{w}}^{\text{end}}\rVert^{2}_{2}/\lVert{\mathbf{w}}^{\text{end}}-{\mathbf{w}}^{\text{start}}\rVert^{2}_{2},

where we can optimize ℒMTT​(𝒟~)subscriptℒMTT~𝒟\mathcal{L}_{\text{MTT}}(\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}) over 𝒟~~𝒟\widetilde{\mathcal{D}} via gradient descent to obtain the auxiliary synthetic dataset.

Projected Trajectory Regularization. Once we obtain the auxiliary dataset via MTT, the following step is to project the next-step training trajectory and design our federated learning framework. We summarize our design at Algorithm 2 and give more details in the following 111Algorithm 2 focused on the full participation case where all clients participate in each round. For partial participation cases, we can simply allow selected clients to perform MTT from the past trajectories it observed.. Specifically, for each client (after certain training rounds m𝑚m), we utilize MTT for extracting the auxiliary dataset 𝒟~isubscript~𝒟𝑖\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i}. Since the auxiliary dataset is designed to mimic the training trajectory from the (t−m)𝑡𝑚(t-m)-th round global model to the t𝑡t-th round global model, we can obtain our projected next-step model training trajectory 𝐰~it+1superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡1\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{t+1} by further performing several steps of gradient descent training on 𝒟~isubscript~𝒟𝑖\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i} with learning rate η𝜂\eta.

Inspired by FedProx, we also design a proximal term for guiding the local training. Different from FedProx, we don’t use the last-step global model 𝐱tsuperscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}^{t}, instead, we hope the local update to stay close to our projected training trajectory 𝐰~it+1superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡1\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{t+1}:

min𝐰⁡ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)+λ2​∥𝐰−𝐰~it+1∥22,subscript𝐰ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖𝜆2subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐰superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡122\min_{\mathbf{w}}\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i})+\frac{\lambda}{2}\lVert\mathbf{w}-\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{t+1}\rVert^{2}_{2}, (2)

where λ𝜆\lambda controls the strength of the proximal term. Through such a design, we utilized the extracted global information from past training trajectories to help guide the local model update. To make our algorithm more practical and provide more flexibility for local clients, we also follow FedProx and only require a γ𝛾\gamma-inexactness solution during local training. After finishing the local computation, clients will send their updated model to the server and the rest steps follow the same procedure as vanilla FedAvg.

Initialization of the Auxiliary Dataset. Previous studies Cazenavette et al. (2022) have shown that using real data samples from true classes can improve the performance of MTT. However, it is not very practical in federated learning with heterogeneous data distribution, as it is nearly impossible for individual clients to possess real data samples from each class. Hence, we use an alternative strategy to initialize the auxiliary dataset 𝒟~isubscript~𝒟𝑖\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i}. Specifically, for those classes that have corresponding samples in the local training data, we directly random sample (with replacement) the desired amount of real data from the local training data. For those classes that do not have samples in the local training data, we adopt the random initialization strategy.

Adaptive Regularization Parameter. In Eq (2), we use a standard squared L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm regularization as the proximal term. Following common machine learning practices, we usually adopt a constant λ𝜆\lambda as the regularization parameter. However, one thing we notice is that in practice, when applied this L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm regularization in neural network models, the model difference 𝐰−𝐰~it+1𝐰superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡1\mathbf{w}-\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{t+1} can vary drastically among different convolutional layers222see more details in Appendix B.1. This motivates us to use a layer-adaptive λ𝜆\lambda rather than a constant. Specifically, let 𝐰[j]subscript𝐰delimited-[]𝑗\mathbf{w}_{[j]} denotes parameters for the j𝑗j-th layer in 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and 𝐰~i,[j]t+1subscriptsuperscript~𝐰𝑡1𝑖delimited-[]𝑗\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}^{t+1}_{i,[j]} denotes parameters for the j𝑗j-th layer in 𝐰~~𝐰\mathbf{\widetilde{w}}, we can define the adaptive λjsubscript𝜆𝑗\lambda_{j} as follows: λj=λ/∥𝐰[j]−𝐰~i,[j]t+1∥2.subscript𝜆𝑗𝜆subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰delimited-[]𝑗subscriptsuperscript~𝐰𝑡1𝑖delimited-[]𝑗2\lambda_{j}=\lambda/\lVert\mathbf{w}_{[j]}-\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}^{t+1}_{i,[j]}\rVert_{2}.In practice, we find that using layer adaptive λ𝜆\lambda can increase the performance and we report all our experimental results in Experiments with the layer adaptive λ𝜆\lambda by default.

Server-Side FedPTR. One problem of FedPTR presented in Algorithm 2 is that each client needs to perform Matching Training Trajectories and update their own auxiliary dataset in each communication round, which would introduce extra computation costs. In order to make our method smoothly accommodate resource-constrained devices (e.g., mobile phones, robots, drone swarms), we also provide a server-side FedPTR algorithm (denoted by FedPTR-S), which only optimizes the auxiliary dataset through MTT in the global server as shown in Algorithm 3. Specifically, in each communication round, the global server first starts to match training trajectories and optimize a unified 𝐰~t+1superscript~𝐰𝑡1\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}^{t+1}. Then, each client will receive both 𝐰tsuperscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{t} and 𝐰~t+1superscript~𝐰𝑡1\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}^{t+1} for local training. Note that different from client-side FedPTR as shown in Algorithm 2, the server-side version initializes the auxiliary dataset using random noise without any real data from local clients. Therefore, our FedPTR-S can preserve data privacy while also making participating devices free from extra computation burdens.

4 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we provide the theoretical convergence analysis for the proposed FedPTR framework. We first state several assumptions needed for the convergence analysis.

Assumption 4.1.

The loss function on the i𝑖i-th client ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i}) is L𝐿L-smooth, i.e., ∀𝐰,𝐯∈ℝdfor-all𝐰𝐯superscriptℝ𝑑\forall\mathbf{w},\mathbf{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, |ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)−ℒ​(𝐯;𝒟i)−⟨∇ℒ​(𝐯;𝒟i),𝐰−𝐯⟩|≤L2​‖𝐰−𝐯‖22ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖ℒ𝐯subscript𝒟𝑖∇ℒ𝐯subscript𝒟𝑖𝐰𝐯𝐿2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐰𝐯22\big{|}\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i})-\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{v};\mathcal{D}_{i})-\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{v};\mathcal{D}_{i}),\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{v}\rangle\big{|}\leq\frac{L}{2}\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{v}\|_{2}^{2}. This also implies the L𝐿L-gradient Lipschitz condition: ‖∇ℒ​(𝐯;𝒟i)−∇ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)‖2≤L​‖𝐰−𝐯‖2subscriptnorm∇ℒ𝐯subscript𝒟𝑖∇ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖2𝐿subscriptnorm𝐰𝐯2\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{v};\mathcal{D}_{i})-\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i})\|_{2}\leq L\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{v}\|_{2}.

Assumption 4.2.

The gradient of the local loss function on the i𝑖i-th client ∇ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)∇ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i}) is B𝐵B-locally dissimilar, i.e., 1N​∑i∈[N]‖∇ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)‖22≤B2​‖∇ℒ​(𝐰)‖221𝑁subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑁superscriptsubscriptnorm∇ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖22superscript𝐵2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇ℒ𝐰22\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i\in[N]}\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i})\|_{2}^{2}\leq B^{2}\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})\|_{2}^{2}.

Assumption 4.1 and 4.2 are standard assumptions in federated learning optimization problems Acar et al. (2021); Li et al. (2020); Karimireddy et al. (2020b); Xu et al. (2021); Gao et al. (2022). Assumption 4.2 describes the dissimilarity between the gradient of local objectives and the global objective. Note that the commonly used Li et al. (2020); Reddi et al. (2020); Wang et al. (2022b) bounded variance assumption, 1N​∑i∈[N]‖∇ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)−∇ℒ​(𝐰)‖2≤σ21𝑁subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑁superscriptnorm∇ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖∇ℒ𝐰2superscript𝜎2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i\in[N]}\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i})-\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})\|^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}, also satisfies the condition in Assumption 4.2.

Assumption 4.3.

The auxiliary loss function on the i𝑖i-th client ℒ~​(𝐰;𝒟~i)~ℒ𝐰subscript~𝒟𝑖\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}(\mathbf{w};\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i}) has ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-bounded gradient dissimilarity with global objective ℒ​(𝐰)ℒ𝐰\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}), i.e., ∀𝐰∈ℝdfor-all𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\forall\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, it satisfies ‖∇ℒ​(𝐰)−∇ℒ~​(𝐰;𝒟~i)‖22≤σd2.superscriptsubscriptnorm∇ℒ𝐰∇~ℒ𝐰subscript~𝒟𝑖22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}(\mathbf{w};\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i})\|_{2}^{2}\leq\sigma_{d}^{2}.

Assumption 4.3 measures the gradient dissimilarity between the global loss function and the training loss on the auxiliary dataset 𝒟~isubscript~𝒟𝑖\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i}, which implies that the MTT algorithm is actually well functioning: the extracted auxiliary dataset indeed mimics the actual global model training trajectories.

In the following, we will state the theoretical convergence analysis for our proposed FedPTR. For expository purposes, we assume K=1𝐾1K=1, i.e., performing 1 step of auxiliary model update in each round, though our convergence analysis can also be extended to cases when K>1𝐾1K>1.

Theorem 4.4 (Non-convex FedPTR convergence).

Under Assumptions 4.1-4.3, assume the local objective functions ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i}) are non-convex, and there exists L−>0subscript𝐿0L_{-}>0, such that ∇ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)⪰−L−​𝐈succeeds-or-equals∇ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝐿𝐈\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i})\succeq-L_{-}\mathbf{I} with μ=λ−L−>0𝜇𝜆subscript𝐿0\mu=\lambda-L_{-}>0. If η≤12​λ𝜂12𝜆\eta\leq\frac{1}{2\lambda}, γ𝛾\gamma is selected to be sufficient small, μ𝜇\mu and λ𝜆\lambda satisfies

16​λ−4​L2λ​μ2−2​L2λ​μ2−1λ​N−2​Lμ2−4​Lμ2≥0,16𝜆4superscript𝐿2𝜆superscript𝜇22superscript𝐿2𝜆superscript𝜇21𝜆𝑁2𝐿superscript𝜇24𝐿superscript𝜇20\displaystyle\frac{1}{6\lambda}-\frac{4L^{2}}{\lambda\mu^{2}}-\frac{2L^{2}}{\lambda\mu^{2}}-\frac{1}{\lambda N}-\frac{2L}{\mu^{2}}-\frac{4L}{\mu^{2}}\geq 0, (3)

then the iterations of FedPTR satisfy

mint∈[T]⁡𝔼​[‖∇ℒ​(𝐰t)‖22]≤𝒪​(𝔼​[ℒ​(𝐰0)]−𝔼​[ℒ​(𝐰T)]6​λ​T)+𝒪​(η2​σd2).subscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥∇ℒsubscript𝐰𝑡22𝒪𝔼delimited-[]ℒsubscript𝐰0𝔼delimited-[]ℒsubscript𝐰𝑇6𝜆𝑇𝒪superscript𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2\begin{split}\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}_{t})\|_{2}^{2}]\leq&\mathcal{O}\bigg{(}\frac{\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}_{0})]-\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}_{T})]}{6\lambda T}\bigg{)}\\ &\quad+\mathcal{O}(\eta^{2}\sigma_{d}^{2}).\end{split} (4)

The proof of Theorem 4.4 is provided in Appendix A. Theorem 4.4 suggests that the gradient norm of FedPTR has an upper bound that contains two terms. The first term vanishes as the communication round T𝑇T increases and the second term is related to σd2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2\sigma_{d}^{2}, i.e., the gradient dissimilarity between global training loss and the training loss on the auxiliary dataset. This implies that if the auxiliary gradient differs significantly from the global gradient, it will hurt FedPTR’s performance as larger σdsubscript𝜎𝑑\sigma_{d} leads to worse convergence.

In such a case, the auxiliary gradient cannot well-represent the global gradient direction, hence to obtain a desired convergence performance, it requires a smaller η𝜂\eta to control the auxiliary model 𝐰~t+1subscript~𝐰𝑡1\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{t+1} to stay close to the global initial model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} and obtain smaller second term in Eq (4).

Remark 4.5.

Theorem 4.4 could be extended to our proposed server-side FedPTR (Algorithm 3) with slighly modifying Assumption 4.3 to ‖∇ℒ​(𝐰)−∇ℒ~​(𝐰;𝒟~)‖22≤σd2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇ℒ𝐰∇~ℒ𝐰~𝒟22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑑2\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}(\mathbf{w};\widetilde{\mathcal{D}})\|_{2}^{2}\leq\sigma_{d}^{2}, which describes the dissimilarity between the server-side auxiliary loss and the global objective function.

Corollary 4.6.

If choosing the auxiliary learning rate as η=Θ​(1/T)𝜂Θ1𝑇\eta=\Theta(1/\sqrt{T}), then the convergence rate for Algorithm 2 satisfies mint∈[T]⁡𝔼​[‖∇ℒ​(𝐰t)‖22]=𝒪​(1/T)subscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm∇ℒsuperscript𝐰𝑡22𝒪1𝑇\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w}^{t})\|_{2}^{2}]=\mathcal{O}(1/T).

Corollary 4.6 suggests that with an appropriately chosen learning rate, FedPTR achieves a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T) in stochastic non-convex optimization settings, which matches the convergence rate of federated learning with proximal term such as FedProx Li et al. (2020) and FedDyn Acar et al. (2021).

5 Experiments

In this section, we present comprehensive experimental results to show the effectiveness of FedPTR when competing with other state-of-the-art federated learning methods under various heterogeneous data partitions. We first introduce our experimental settings in Section 5.1 and give a detailed analysis of our experimental results and ablation study in the following sections. We report the average accuracy of the last five global rounds on the test set.

5.1 Experimental Settings

Datasets. We conduct experiments on four benchmark datasets: FashionMNIST Xiao et al. (2017), CIFAR10 Krizhevsky et al. (2009) CIFAR100 Krizhevsky et al. (2009), and TinyImageNet Le and Yang (2015). We follow the commonly used mechanism to perform data partition through Dirichlet distribution Wang et al. (2020a). The parameter α𝛼\alpha used in Dirichlet sampling determines the non-i.i.d degree. with smaller α𝛼\alpha, non-i.i.d degree becomes higher. In our experiments, we focus on the high-level data heterogeneity with α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 and α=0.04𝛼0.04\alpha=0.04.

Baselines. We compare our method FedPTR (and FedPTR-S) with five state-of-the-art federated learning methods: FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017), FedProx Li et al. (2020), SCAFFOLD Karimireddy et al. (2020b), FedDyn Acar et al. (2021), and FedDC Gao et al. (2022). All the baseline methods except FedAvg contain utilization of the global information especially on the consistency of the global model and local model while FedPTR integrates the global information by training an auxiliary dataset based on the global parameters.

Hyper-parameters and Model Architectures. In our experiments, we set the batch size as 500 and the local training epoch as 1. By default, we use SGD with a learning rate η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01 and momentum of 0.50.50.5 as the optimizer. We use 10 images per class for FashionMNIST/CIFAR10 and 2 images per class for CIFAR100. We set trajectory projection steps K=5𝐾5K=5 and the base λ𝜆\lambda for layer-adaptive regularization parameter as λ=0.05𝜆0.05\lambda=0.05. We also tune the hyperparameters in all other baselines for their best performances. In matching training trajectories part (Algorithm 1), following Cazenavette et al. (2022), we utilize a learnable β𝛽\beta with initialized β=0.01𝛽0.01\beta=0.01, trajectory matching outer steps H=20𝐻20H=20, inner steps R=10𝑅10R=10, while the rest of the MTT hyper-parameters are set as the default value in Cazenavette et al. (2022). In terms of the model architecture, we follow Cazenavette et al. (2022) and adopt ConvNetGidaris and Komodakis (2018) as the default CNN architecture.

5.2 Comparison of Different Federated Learning Methods on Heterogeneous Data

We compare our method FedPTR (and FedPTR-S) with five state-of-the-art federated learning optimization methods: FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017), FedProx Li et al. (2020), SCAFFOLD Karimireddy et al. (2020b), FedDyn Acar et al. (2021), and FedDC Gao et al. (2022), on varying data heterogeneity, the number of clients, and participation rate. Table 1 shows the comparison results of our method FedPTR with baselines for the scenario of full participation and partial participation with 10 clients. We perform evaluations on two different heterogeneous data partitions, Dirichlet ​α=0.04Dirichlet 𝛼0.04\text{Dirichlet }\alpha=0.04 and Dirichlet ​α=0.01Dirichlet 𝛼0.01\text{Dirichlet }\alpha=0.01. In the full participation setting (participation ratio 100%percent100100\%), we observe that our method outperforms previous methods regarding test accuracy on all datasets. In particular, we achieve the absolute improvement of 6.75%percent6.756.75\% compared with the best-performing baseline FedDyn and over 12%percent1212\% improvement over other baselines on CIFAR10 dataset with Dirichlet ​α=0.01Dirichlet 𝛼0.01\text{Dirichlet }\alpha=0.01. Moreover, it can be seen that previous methods suffer from performance decreases of up to 16.38%percent16.3816.38\% when the data partition becomes more heterogeneous (i.e., from Dirichlet ​α=0.04Dirichlet 𝛼0.04\text{Dirichlet }\alpha=0.04 to Dirichlet ​α=0.01Dirichlet 𝛼0.01\text{Dirichlet }\alpha=0.01), while our method only reduces the test accuracy by up to 4.91%percent4.914.91\%. Such results demonstrate that our method is consistently robust against extremely heterogeneous training data. In partial participation, we evaluate our method and baselines with 50%percent5050\% and 30%percent3030\% participation ratios. We can see that our method obtains relative improvements of 0.9%∼17.7%similar-topercent0.9percent17.70.9\%\sim 17.7\% and 1.2%∼19.3%similar-topercent1.2percent19.31.2\%\sim 19.3\% on 50%percent5050\% participation and 30%percent3030\% participation scenarios compared with FedAvg. These results clearly show the effectiveness of our method for the scenario of partial participation. To further verify our method in the scenario of more clients. We additionally compare FedPTR with baselines in 40 clients and 25%percent2525\% participation ratio as shown in Table 2. We observe that our method FedPTR (and FedPTR-S) still maintains excellent performance compared with the previous methods. Note that in the setting of Dirichlet α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01, we only evaluate our method on CIFAR100 since FashionMNIST and CIFAR10 with fewer categories cannot make each client have training data. We defer the experiments on TinyImageNet in Appendix B.5.

5.3 Reducing the Updates of Auxiliary Dataset

The original design of FedPTR (FedPTR-S) requires the clients/server to update the auxiliary datasets in each communication round. In this section, we explore how performance scales if we reduce the frequency of the auxiliary dataset updates. In Figure 1, we compare the test accuracy against the communication rounds on CIFAR10 Dirichlet ​α=0.01Dirichlet 𝛼0.01\text{Dirichlet }\alpha=0.01 by performing one MTT update per 1, 4, 10, and 40 rounds. We additionally try a one-shot MTT strategy by only updating the auxiliary dataset once. Note that when there is no MTT update over the auxiliary dataset, we still need to perform the trajectory projection step (with the “old” auxiliary dataset) for local update regularization. We find that our proposed FedPTR method does not suffer much in performance even when the number of updates of the auxiliary dataset is reduced by 75%percent7575\%. Moreover, even the most efficient FedPTR with one-shot MTT can still outperform the other baseline methods such as FedDyn Acar et al. (2021) on CIFAR10. See more results on FedPTR-S in Appendix B.3.

5.4 Changing the Size of Auxiliary Dataset

We study how the size of the auxiliary dataset affects our final performances. For this, we conduct experiments comparing FedPTR using different sizes of the auxiliary dataset on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 dataset and show the results in Table 3. For CIFAR10, we explore 5 different sizes, and the results suggest that a moderate size of the auxiliary dataset leads to the best model training performances. When the size is below 100100100, the test accuracy is largely affected due to less representation power limited by the auxiliary dataset size. On the other hand, when the size grows beyond 100100100, there is a clear marginal effect and the influence of the size is not as obvious as before (may even lose performances due to insufficient optimization of the large auxiliary data). For CIFAR100 data, a similar trend can also be observed. Note that using a larger auxiliary dataset leads to a larger computational cost when performing MTT updates in each communication round. In practice, we would be picking a moderate auxiliary dataset size (such as 100100100) for the best of both performance and computational cost.

5.5 Quality of Extracted Global Information

In this subsection, we give a brief analysis on the quality of the extracted global information by the auxiliary dataset. To do so, we measure the similarity between the gradient of the training loss on the auxiliary dataset (denoted by the auxiliary gradient) and the global gradient. A high similarity between the two gradients could indicate that extracted auxiliary datasets well-approximate the recent learning dynamics and can well project the next-step training trajectory. For computational simplicity, here we directly use the global update direction on the server to approximate the global gradient direction, i.e., 𝐰t−𝐰t+1superscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbf{w}^{t}-\mathbf{w}^{t+1}. And we use 𝐰t−𝐰~it+1superscript𝐰𝑡subscriptsuperscript~𝐰𝑡1𝑖\mathbf{w}^{t}-\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}^{t+1}_{i} to approximate the auxiliary gradient. To further demonstrate the quality of extracted global information, we also compute the cosine similarity of local gradient 𝐰t−𝐰it+1superscript𝐰𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡1𝑖\mathbf{w}^{t}-\mathbf{w}^{t+1}_{i} and global gradient. Note that we compute two cosine similarities on vanilla FedAvg, i.e., clients keep the update of the auxiliary dataset and projected training trajectory while not using any regularization term to avoid the auxiliary dataset influencing the training gradient. We present our results for one randomly chosen client in training a CIFAR100 model with Dirichlet α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 in Figure 2. Compared with the local gradient, the auxiliary gradient has a much higher similarity to the global gradient, which suggests that FedPTR can indeed excavate global information from the model training trajectory. Note that the cosine similarity of the auxiliary gradient and global gradient decreases with the increase of the communication rounds. This suggests that it is harder to extract global information at the later phase of model training. Nevertheless, we can still find that the auxiliary gradient shares greater similarity to the global gradient direction compared with the local gradient along the entire training trajectory.

5.6 Ablation Study

One of the important hyperparameters of FedPTR is the weight of the regularization term λ𝜆\lambda. To test its sensitivity, we consider the non-i.i.d. setting of full participation on CIFAR10 with Dirichlet ​α=0.01Dirichlet 𝛼0.01\text{Dirichlet }\alpha=0.01. We conduct the sensitive test from the candidate set {0.01,0.05,0.1,0.2,1.0}0.010.050.10.21.0\{0.01,0.05,0.1,0.2,1.0\}. Figure 3 shows the convergence plot at varying λ𝜆\lambda, while we keep all other hyperparameters of FedPTR consistent. We can observe that the best test accuracy is obtained when λ=0.1𝜆0.1\lambda=0.1. The small λ𝜆\lambda (e.g., 0.01) may not have any effect, and the large λ𝜆\lambda (e.g., 1.0) possibly force 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} to be close to 𝐰~iKsuperscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖𝐾\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{{K}} thus causing slow convergence. We defer more ablation studies on the trajectory matching/projecting steps, layer-adaptive regularization, and different initialization strategies in Appendix B.2.

6 Conclusion

Data heterogeneity issue is a critical factor for the practical deployment of Federated Learning algorithms. In this work, we propose a novel federated learning framework FedPTR that handles extreme data heterogeneity across local clients. The proposed method allows each client or the server to extract essential global information from the observed global model training trajectory and utilize it to project the next-step model trajectory for local training regularization. The exhaustive experimental results on various benchmark datasets and different non-i.i.d settings clearly demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed FedPTR in training real-world machine learning models. One potential limitation of FedPTR is that it cannot be directly applied to language tasks since the application of MTT on language tasks is still an open question. We will leave it as our feature work.

Appendix A Proof of Theorem 4.4.

For notation convenience, we conclude ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟i)ℒ𝐰subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{i}) as ℒi​(𝐰)subscriptℒ𝑖𝐰\mathcal{L}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) and L​(𝐰;𝒟~i)𝐿𝐰subscript~𝒟𝑖L(\mathbf{w};\widetilde{\mathcal{D}}_{i}) as ℒ~i​(𝐰)subscript~ℒ𝑖𝐰\widetilde{\mathcal{L}}_{i}(\mathbf{w}) in the following.

Lemma A.1.

For hi​(𝐰):=ℒi​(𝐰)+λ2​‖𝐰−𝐰t+η​∇ℒ~i​(𝐰t)‖2assignsubscriptℎ𝑖𝐰subscriptℒ𝑖𝐰𝜆2superscriptnorm𝐰superscript𝐰𝑡𝜂∇subscript~ℒ𝑖superscript𝐰𝑡2h_{i}(\mathbf{w}):=\mathcal{L}_{i}(\mathbf{w})+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{t}+\eta\nabla\tilde{\mathcal{L}}_{i}(\mathbf{w}^{t})\|^{2}, there is ‖∇hi​(𝐰)−∇hi​(𝐯)‖≤(L+λ)​‖𝐰−𝐯‖,∀𝐰,𝐯∈ℝdformulae-sequencenorm∇subscriptℎ𝑖𝐰∇subscriptℎ𝑖𝐯𝐿𝜆norm𝐰𝐯for-all𝐰𝐯superscriptℝ𝑑\|\nabla h_{i}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla h_{i}(\mathbf{v})\|\leq(L+\lambda)\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{v}\|,\forall\mathbf{w},\mathbf{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Proof of Lemma A.1.
‖∇hi​(𝐰)−∇hi​(𝐲)‖norm∇subscriptℎ𝑖𝐰∇subscriptℎ𝑖𝐲\displaystyle\|\nabla h_{i}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla h_{i}(\mathbf{y})\|

This concludes the proof. ∎

This concludes the proof. ∎

Appendix B Additional Experiments

B.1 More Experiments on Layer Adaptive λ𝜆\lambda

In Figure 4, we plot the L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norms of the four different convolutional layers in ConvNetGidaris and Komodakis (2018), with the model trained under a 10-clients federated learning setup, and each client’s training data sampled from the original CIFAR10 dataset following Dirichlet distribution (α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01). We can observe that the L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm of 𝐰−𝐰~it+1𝐰superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑖𝑡1\mathbf{w}-\widetilde{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{t+1} between layers varies and it also changes along with different phases of training. For example, at the beginning of training, the fourth layer has the largest L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm while the second layer has the largest L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm when the training is about to end. Such a phenomenon indicates that it might be helpful to use a layer-adaptive λ𝜆\lambda rather than a constant. We compare our layer adaptive λ𝜆\lambda with the standard fixed λ𝜆\lambda. We report results on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 with the parameter of Dirichlet distribution α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 and 0.040.040.04 as shown in Table 4. We can observe that our FedPTR adopting layer adaptive λ𝜆\lambda achieves better performances compared with the fixed λ𝜆\lambda setting. More experiments compared with layer adaptive λ𝜆\lambda and fixed λ𝜆\lambda can be found in the following section.

B.2 More Results of Ablation Study

Impact of trajectory projecting steps. To test sensitivity of the trajectory projection steps K𝐾K, we consider CIIFAR10 with Dirichlet 0.010.010.01. Figure 5 shows convergence plots for different K𝐾K configurations. We can observe that our method is relatively stable when k=3𝑘3k=3 and k=5𝑘5k=5. However, setting k=1𝑘1k=1 would lead to slower convergence and a slight performance decrease, and setting k=10𝑘10k=10 could accelerate the training in the early stage but result in instability and make it difficult to converge.

Different Initialization Strategies. As presented in Table 5, we compare our strategy that initializes the auxiliary dataset using (partial) local client data with the random initialization strategy. It can be seen that FedPTR using our proposed initialization strategy obtains better performance on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 with the improvement of 1.54%percent1.541.54\% and 0.47%percent0.470.47\%, respectively. On the other hand, our FedPTR still maintains excellent performance even after adopting the random initialization strategy, which supports the design of server-side FedPTR (FedPTR-S) that performs MTT and optimizes the auxiliary dataset with random initialization in the global server.

Impact of trajectory matching steps. In Table 6, we present the performance of our server’s side method FedPTR-S on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively, with varying total trajectory matching steps H𝐻H used in Algorithm 1. Specifically, we consider 10 clients, full participation setting with two different non-iid data participation Dirichlet α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 and Dirichlet α=0.04𝛼0.04\alpha=0.04. We can see that our method is stable with respect to different trajectory matching steps. Even if we reduce the steps from 20 to 5, the test accuracy obtained on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 only decreases by 1.16%percent1.161.16\% and 0.5%percent0.50.5\%, respectively.

Layer-adaptive λ𝜆\lambda V.S. Fixed λ𝜆\lambda. In Table 4, we have already shown the effectiveness of layer-adaptive λ𝜆\lambda, and here we give a further analysis. As shown in Figure 6, we present the complete convergence plots of FedPTR with layer-adaptive λ𝜆\lambda and fixed λ𝜆\lambda on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 with Dirichlet α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 and Dirichlet α=0.04𝛼0.04\alpha=0.04. It can be seen that adopting layer-adaptive λ𝜆\lambda slightly falls behind at the beginning of the training but obtains better performance in the late phase of the training, indicating that layer-adaptive λ𝜆\lambda can help converge to a better stationary point.

B.3 More Results of Reducing the Updates of Auxiliary Dataset

For the update frequency, we have conducted ablation studies on client’s side as shown in Figure 1. Following the same setting, here we present our experiments on server’s side in Table 7, which shows that the server-side method FedPTR-S can still maintain a relatively stable performance with reduced updates of auxiliary datasets.

B.4 More Results of Changing the Size of Auxiliary Dataset.

We have conducted comparisons of the client’s side method FedPTR with different sizes of the auxiliary dataset on CIFAR10 with Dirichlet α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 as shown in Table 3. Here we present the results on server’s side method FedPTR-S with the same setting as shown in Table 8. We can observe FedPTR-S could obtain better performance with more auxiliary data, similar to FedPTR.

B.5 Experiments on TinyImagenet

We additionally conduct experiments to test our method on larger TinyImageNet data to demonstrate that our method can indeed extend to larger-scale experiments. We summarize the experimental results with 10 clients and Dir α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 in Table 9. The results suggest that our method still outperforms other baselines.

Appendix C Privacy leakage of FedPTR

For privacy leakage of our proposed method, we argue that although we did not add any privacy protection techniques into our framework, FedPTR does not incur extra privacy leakage compared to FedAvgMcMahan et al. (2017)/FedDynAcar et al. (2021) since all the communications between clients and server are model weights/updates, just like FedAvgMcMahan et al. (2017)/FedDynAcar et al. (2021). To empirically demonstrate that FedPTR does not incur extra privacy leakages, we further conduct membership inference attack (MIA) to the final model trained by different methods. We show the MIA results of 10 clients FL with α=0.04𝛼0.04\alpha=0.04 on CIFAR100 dataset in the Table 10 using two well-recognized MIA methods: 1) loss-based method and 2) Likelihood ratio attack (LiRA). Here accuracy means whether the MIA method successfully predicts whether a sample is in the original training set or not. In other words, a MIA test accuracy of a method that is closer to 50% (random guess) indicates this method barely leaks private information. We can observe that FedPTR achieves a similar level of privacy leakage as other baselines such as FedAvgMcMahan et al. (2017)/FedDynAcar et al. (2021), as expected.

Appendix D Detailed Description of Data Sampling

As we have mentioned in experimental settings, for all experiments, we adopt Dirichlet data sampling methods, which are commonly used in federated learning papersAcar et al. (2021); Wang et al. (2020a). For Dirichlet sampling methods, each client j𝑗j is allocated a proportion of the samples from each label k𝑘k according to Dirichlet distribution. Specifically, we sample pk∼D​i​rN​(α)similar-tosubscript𝑝𝑘𝐷𝑖subscript𝑟𝑁𝛼p_{k}\sim Dir_{N}(\alpha) and allocate a pk​jsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑗p_{kj} proportion of data samples of class k𝑘k to client j𝑗j, where D​i​rN​(α)𝐷𝑖subscript𝑟𝑁𝛼Dir_{N}(\alpha) denotes the Dirichlet distribution and α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 is a concentration parameter. A smaller α𝛼\alpha indicates a higher non-i.i.d. degree when sampling data, and we focused on the high-level data heterogeneity with α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 and α=0.04𝛼0.04\alpha=0.04. Table 11 shows a typical Dirichlet sampling result for different settings. We can observe that when choosing 40 clients on CIFAR10, it can easily assign 0 data samples to certain clients due to low value and a small number of classes. That is the reason why we do not conclude experiments with more clients on CIFAR10 and FashionMNIST.

Appendix E Naive Attempt: Combining Distilled Dataset with Local Data

In this section, we present a naive attempt of directly combining distilled dataset with local data and analyze its failed case. Note that MTTCazenavette et al. (2022) is originally proposed for distilling a small synthetic dataset. Thus a trivial idea for tackling data heterogeneity is to apply MTTCazenavette et al. (2022) to obtain the synthetic dataset and combine those distilled data with the available local data to train FedProxLi et al. (2020) for relieving the data heterogeneity. However, this trivial design is not ideal for addressing the data heterogeneity issue especially when data are highly non-i.i.d. distributed among clients, as demonstrated in Table 12. The result shows that simply adding the synthetic data by MTTCazenavette et al. (2022) for FedProx training obtains even worse performance than FedAvg. This is primarily due to the fact that the synthetic data obtained by MTTCazenavette et al. (2022) under federated settings (original MTTCazenavette et al. (2022) can use multiple training trajectories and apply restart strategy which is not realistic under federated setting) may not be ideal enough to fully represent the information inside the original training data. Therefore, directly training on the synthetic data may actually make the training worse. While in our case, we only require the auxiliary data produced by MTTCazenavette et al. (2022) to guide the next-step training trajectory prediction (which is exactly what our MTTCazenavette et al. (2022) is trained for, i.e., to match recent training trajectories). Thus we believe that our methods are fundamentally different from simply combining the previous methods FedProxLi et al. (2020) and MTTCazenavette et al. (2022).
